Header:
Globally, tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death from an infectious disease. Although there has been progress to reduce TB deaths over the past two decades, the current approaches to treating TB remain inadequate. 

TB infection in the lung is associated with the formation of **granulomas**, the result of the immune response to clear the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). Understanding the key interactions between immune cells that occur within the granulomas may help identify ways to improve the diagnosis and treatment of TB.

*Here, we use two images of a lung infected with tuberculosis to illustrate the classical hallmarks of a TB granuloma.* 

First, we show a tissue section of a tuberculosis infected lung stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). H&E images are the gold standard method for diagnosing tuberculosis clinically, so there are many classical hallmarks of TB that can be visualized in this image.

Second, we show a subsequent tissue section that was subjected to tissue cyclic immunofluorescence [(t-CyCIF)](https://elifesciences.org/articles/31657), a cyclical method for antibody staining and fluorescent imaging. Multiplexed imaging can reveal molecular information that could help identify better TB treatments in the future.

Waypoints.Name: Major tissue features
Waypoints.Description:
First, let's get oriented to the major histological features within this sample. Lung tissue is primarily made up of three parts:

1. **Airways** – In the center of the sample, a major airway structure is visible.
2. **Alveoli** - The lung is made up of many air sacs – known as alveoli – where CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2</sub> exchange occurs while breathing. Many alveoli are present in normal lung tissue, as seen on the top left. 
3. **Blood vessels** – Blood vessels are critical for gas exchange in the lung. We highlight two – a cross section in the center of the tissue that has a distinct ring of smooth muscle and another to the right where the length of the vessel is visible.

This lung is infected with tuberculosis and has a number of **granulomas** – these are the active sites of inflammation due to tuberculosis infection. Here, we highlight two but many more are visible. 

The red region in the lower right is a hemorrhage – this tissue sample was taken as a biopsy, so some bleeding has likely happened while the biopsy was being taken. You can zoom in to see the red blood cells in this region.

Waypoints.Name: Normal lung tissue
Waypoints.Description:
When we breathe, air enters the lungs through the **airways**. Airways are lined with epithelial cells that have a very regular columnar structure and appears dark purple in the image due to prominent cell nuclei.

These airways serve as a stem for the numerous **alveoli** (air sacs) that attach to the stem like a bunch of grapes. Most of the empty spaces to the center and right of the image are indicative of these air-containing alveoli. 

Each alveolus is made up of a single cell layer of epithelial cells that encapsulate the air. The alveoli are surrounded externally by capillaries - the smallest blood vessels - which are also a single cell layer thick. Gas exchange – CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2</sub> – happens at the interface of the air-containing alveoli and blood-containing capillaries.

Disruption of the alveoli by tuberculosis can impact the entire process of breathing.

Waypoints.Name: Granulomas - the site of tuberculosis infection
Waypoints.Description:
After the tuberculosis bacteria (Mtb) enters the lungs, the body attempts to clear the infection and heal the tissue. In the case of tuberculosis (TB), this exuberant healing process results in some alveoli of the lung developing into granulomas. 

Granulomas are surrounded by a **fibrotic ring**. This ring is essentially a scar-like structure that results from local fibroblasts and macrophages trying to wall off the infection and prevent the Mtb from spreading.

Early granulomas also have a **caseous necrotic core**. This core is made up of a mass of dead cell debris that is evident from the absence of cell nuclei (purple ovals) throughout the region.

Waypoints.Name: Granulomas - the site of tuberculosis infection
Waypoints.Description: This second granuloma shows the same hallmarks; however, this granuloma is slightly further along in trying to contain the infection and has a thicker fibrotic boundary layer.

Waypoints.Name: Tissue architecture of granulomas in t-CyCIF
Waypoints.Description:
Now let’s switch gears and look at these same two granulomas through highly multiplexed immunofluorescent images. 

This image shows the overall tissue architecture with three markers, DNA (`DNA1`), which indicates cell nuclei, smooth muscle alpha actin (`aSMA`), which labels contractile cells like fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells, and Keratin (`panCK`), which labels epithelial cells.

Waypoints.Name: Taking a closer look at tissue architecture of a TB granuloma
Waypoints.Description:
Zooming into TB granuloma 1, we see that the fibrotic ring at the boundaries stains for `aSMA`. This fibrous boundary prevents the soft, necrotic core from leaking out and affecting nearby lung tissue.

Inside the necrotic core, there is a distinct lack of cell nuclei (`DNA1`). This again illustrates that the core is made of debris from dead cells and mycobacterium. The keratin (`panCK`) in the core is the residue of lung tissue that used to be in this region.

Waypoints.Name: Taking a closer look at tissue architecture of a TB granuloma
Waypoints.Description: Zooming in again, we see the cells (nuclei stained by `DNA1`) that populate the fibrous boundary, but the core is mostly cell-free, except for a few infiltrating immune cells (arrow).

Waypoints.Name: Immune population in a TB granuloma
Waypoints.Description:
Now we turn our attention to the immune cells in this granuloma and use multiplexed imaging to decipher the identities of the local immune cells. 

**B cells (`CD20`)** are antibody producing cells that aggregate at the edge of granulomas. **T cells (`CD3D`)** gather near these B-cell aggregates to support antibody development.

There are also many **macrophages (`CD68`)** within the granuloma. In TB, some macrophages attempt to phagocytose (eat) TB bacteria to neutralize infection, but Mtb is well-equipped to deal with the macrophage’s defense mechanisms. In some macrophage-Mtb interactions, instead of phagocytosis killing the bacteria, the bacteria grow and replicate within the macrophage, a process that ultimately kills the macrophage. Within the core, the macrophage staining (`CD68`) represents debris from macrophages that died after being infected with TB. 

Other macrophages serve as antigen-presenting cells that work with T cells (`CD3D`). Macrophages located close to T cells (`CD3D`) are likely presenting TB antigens to T cells and activating T cells to help fight the infection or kill infected macrophages.

Waypoints.Name: Cytotoxic T cells and T helper cells
Waypoints.Description:
Taking a more in-depth look at the population of T cells in this area, we can distinguish two types of T- cells: cytotoxic T cells, aka “killer cells” (`CD8A`) and T helper cells (`CD4`).

**T helper cells (`CD4`+)** work with antigen-presenting macrophages to fight TB

**Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+)** kill infected macrophages

CD4+ and CD8+ T cells both have important and unique roles, but in TB, T helper cells (`CD4`) are essential to controlling the infection. The lack of functioning T helper cells (`CD4`) is a key reason why TB is particularly lethal to HIV-positive people who often have depleted `CD4`+ T cell populations.
